newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico Cetes rate ends off, shadows U.S. long bond.
newsitem.headline: Mexico Cetes rate ends off, shadows U.S. long bond.

text.p: Mexican overnight Cetes rates ended down just 10 basis points at 21.90 percent on Tuesday in a move that mirrored U.S. long bond yields, traders said.
"Overnight Cetes rates closed down because of the (U.S. long) bond yield, which zigzagged through the session, but ended down, which also bolstered the peso," a trader said.
Benchmark 48-hour pesos contracts closed unchanged at 7.9120/7.9140 per dollar.
U.S. 30-year Treasury bonds were up 6/32 to yield 7.08 percent as the money market was closing in Mexico, after being down 5/32 in early trade to yield 7.12 percent.
Another dealer said the session had been volatile due to concern the Federal Open Market Committee would raise U.S. interest rates again in May.
"We expect the upward trend to continue and that, mainly, has led to both uncertainty and jitters in the Mexican market," he said.
Traders and analysts thus estimated primary interest rates would gain after two weeks of decreases at Banco de Mexico's primary auction to be held later in the day.

Money market traders surveyed by Reuters showed they forecast the central bank would assign bellwether 27-day Cetes at an average rate of 21.22 percent. This would be a gain of 63 basis points since last week's auction.
Auction results are due out at 1830 local time/0030 GMT.
Banco de Mexico drained 2.961 billion pesos through six secondary auctions, which it assigned at rates of between 23.73 and 23.84 percent, at maturities of between one and 16 days.
Overnight rates on bank paper, meanwhile, closed up 50 basis points at 23.90 percent.
Liquidity of 1.843 billion pesos was scheduled to return to the system from prior central bank participation.
